message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Quantifying the local adaptive landscape of a nascent bacterial community
Paper Abstract: Abstract The fitness effects of all possible mutations available to an organism largely shape the dynamics of evolutionary adaptation. Yet, whether and how this adaptive landscape changes over evolutionary times, especially upon ecological diversification and changes in community composition, remains poorly understood. We sought to fill this gap by analyzing a stable community of two closely related ecotypes (“L” and “S”) shortly after they emerged within the E. coli Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE). We engineered genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries to measure the invasion fitness effects of all possible gene knockouts in the coexisting strains as well as their ancestor, for many different, ecologically relevant conditions. We find consistent statistical patterns of fitness effect variation across both genetic background and community composition, despite the idiosyncratic behavior of individual knockouts. Additionally, fitness effects are correlated with evolutionary outcomes for a number of conditions, possibly revealing shifting patterns of adaptation. Together, our results reveal how ecological and epistatic effects combine to shape the adaptive landscape in a nascent ecological community.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Ecological diversification"

Links: [{"title":"Ecosystem diversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_diversity"},{"title":"Redonda (butterfly) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redonda_(genus)"},{"title":"Ecosystem service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_services;"},{"title":"Great Oxidation Event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_oxygenation_event"},{"title":"Sympatric speciation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sympatric_speciation"},{"title":"Réunion National Park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9union_National_Park"}]

Here are the search results for "Ecological diversification":

## Key Findings

**Definition and Scope:**
Ecological diversity includes the variation in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems and can take into account the variation in the complexity of a biological community, including the number of different niches and ecological processes.

**Examples of Ecological Diversity:**
An example of ecological diversity on a global scale would be the variation in ecosystems, such as deserts, forests, grasslands, wetlands and oceans.

**Evolutionary Drivers:**
Ecological diversity around the world can be directly linked to the evolutionary and selective pressures that constrain the diversity outcome of the ecosystems within different niches, with tundras, rainforests, coral reefs and deciduous forests all formed as a result of evolutionary pressures.

**Examples in Nature:**
The search results provide specific examples of ecological diversification. Island isolation and diversity of habitats and microclimates have favored the diversification of a highly endemic flora, with 230 endemic plant species out of 850 known native plant species on Réunion Island.

**Biodiversity and Ecosystem Stability:**
The portfolio effect compares biodiversity to stock holdings, where diversification minimizes the volatility of the investment, or in this case, the risk of instability of ecosystem services through response diversity where a suite of species will exhibit differential responses to environmental perturbations.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Gene knockout"

Links: [{"title":"Gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockout"},{"title":"Conditional gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_gene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene knock-in - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knock-in"},{"title":"Knockout mouse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_mouse"},{"title":"Gene knockdown - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockdown"},{"title":"DMRT1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMRT1"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk%3AGene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene silencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_silencing"},{"title":"Martin Hrabě de Angelis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Hrab%C4%95_de_Angelis"},{"title":"Knockout moss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_moss"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about gene knockout:

## Definition and Overview

Gene knockouts (also known as gene deletion or gene inactivation) are a widely used genetic engineering technique that involves the targeted removal or inactivation of a specific gene within an organism's genome.(no content)This can be done through a variety of methods, including homologous recombination, CRISPR-Cas9, and TALENs.

## Purpose and Benefits

One of the main advantages of gene knockouts is that they allow researchers to study the function of a specific gene in vivo, and to understand the role of the gene in normal development and physiology as well as in the pathology of diseases.(no content)By studying the phenotype of the organism with the knocked out gene, researchers can gain insights into the biological processes that the gene is involved in.

## Types of Knockouts

There are two main types of gene knockouts: complete and conditional. A complete gene knockout permanently inactivates the gene, while a conditional gene knockout allows for the gene to be turned off and on at specific times or in specific tissues.

## Applications

Gene knockouts have been widely used in many different organisms, including bacteria, yeast, fruit flies, zebrafish, and mice. In mice, gene knockouts are commonly used to study the function of specific genes in development, physiology, and cancer research.

## Multiple Gene Knockouts

Knocking out two genes simultaneously in an organism is known as a double knockout (DKO). Similarly the terms triple knockout (TKO) and quadruple knockouts (QKO) are used to describe three or four knocked out genes, respectively.

Web search results for query: "E. coli bacteria"

Links: [{"title":"Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"2006 North American E. coli outbreak in spinach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_North_American_E._coli_outbreak_in_spinach"},{"title":"E. coli long-term evolution experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._coli_long-term_evolution_experiment"},{"title":"1996 Odwalla E. coli outbreak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_E._coli_case_from_Odwalla_juice"},{"title":"Escherichia coli O157:H7 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli_O157:H7"},{"title":"2024 McDonald's E. coli outbreak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_McDonald's_E._coli_outbreak"},{"title":"Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enteroaggregative_Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"Enterobacteria phage T2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterobacteria_phage_T2"},{"title":"23S ribosomal RNA - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/23S_ribosomal_RNA"},{"title":"Cloning vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning_vector"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about E. coli bacteria:

## What is E. coli?

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.(no content)E. coli is a bacterium that is normally found in the human intestine, but some strains of bacteria can cause illness and infection.

## Characteristics

Optimum growth of E. coli occurs at 37 °C (99 °F), but some laboratory strains can multiply at temperatures up to 49 °C (120 °F).(no content)E. coli is classified as a facultative anaerobe. It uses oxygen when it is present and available. It can, however, continue to grow in the absence of oxygen using fermentation or anaerobic respiration.

## Scientific and Medical Uses

Cloning is generally first performed using Escherichia coli, and cloning vectors in E. coli include plasmids, bacteriophages (such as phage λ), cosmids, and bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs).

## Pathogenic Strains

Escherichia coli O157:H7 is a serotype of the bacterial species Escherichia coli and is one of the Shiga-like toxin–producing types of E. coli.(no content)It is highly virulent, with a low infectious dose: an inoculation of fewer than 10 to 100 colony-forming units (CFU) of E. coli O157:H7 is sufficient to cause infection.

## What is E. coli?

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.(no content)E. coli is a bacterium that is normally found in the human intestine, but some strains of bacteria can cause illness and infection.

## Characteristics

Optimum growth of E. coli occurs at 37 °C (99 °F), but some laboratory strains can multiply at temperatures up to 49 °C (120 °F).(no content)E. coli is classified as a facultative anaerobe. It uses oxygen when it is present and available. It can, however, continue to grow in the absence of oxygen using fermentation or anaerobic respiration.

## Scientific and Medical Uses

Cloning is generally first performed using Escherichia coli, and cloning vectors in E. coli include plasmids, bacteriophages (such as phage λ), cosmids, and bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs).

## Pathogenic Strains

Escherichia coli O157:H7 is a serotype of the bacterial species Escherichia coli and is one of the Shiga-like toxin–producing types of E. coli.(no content)It is highly virulent, with a low infectious dose: an inoculation of fewer than 10 to 100 colony-forming units (CFU) of E. coli O157:H7 is sufficient to cause infection.

Links: [{"title":"Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis"},{"title":"Epistasis and functional genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis_and_functional_genomics"},{"title":"Additive genetic effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Additive_genetic_effects"},{"title":"Labrador Retriever coat colour genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labrador_Retriever_coat_colour_genetics"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genetics"},{"title":"Polygene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygene"},{"title":"Hypostatic gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostatic_gene"},{"title":"Punnett square - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punnett_square"},{"title":"Association mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_mapping"},{"title":"Inclusive composite interval mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_composite_interval_mapping"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about epistasis in genetics:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

## Historical Context

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

## Classical Genetics Examples

In classical genetics, if genes A and B are mutated, and each mutation by itself produces a unique phenotype but the two mutations together show the same phenotype as the gene A mutation, then gene A is epistatic and gene B is hypostatic.(no content)For example, the gene for total baldness is epistatic to the gene for brown hair. Another well-documented example involves coat color in Labrador Retrievers, where their interaction in affecting the trait of coat colour is used by biology textbooks to demonstrate the genetic principle of epistasis, where multiple genes react synergistically to affect a single trait.

## Types of Epistasis

When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, it is referred to as positive epistasis. Positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected. Positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.(no content)Conversely, when two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Recent human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recent_human_evolution"},{"title":"Maladaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maladaptation"},{"title":"Lamarckism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamarckism"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Exaptation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exaptation"},{"title":"Urban evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_evolution"},{"title":"Human skeletal changes due to bipedalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_skeletal_changes_due_to_bipedalism"},{"title":"Theoretical foundations of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_foundations_of_evolutionary_psychology"}]

I've completed the web search for "Evolution adaptation." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

In biology, adaptation has three related meanings. Firstly, it is the dynamic evolutionary process of natural selection that fits organisms to their environment, enhancing their evolutionary fitness.(no content)Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations. It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within a population over successive generations.

## How Adaptations Work

Most prominent are the specific behavioral and physical adaptations that are the outcome of natural selection. These adaptations increase fitness by aiding activities such as finding food, avoiding predators or attracting mates.

## Examples in Nature

Two or more species co-adapt and co-evolve as they develop adaptations that interlock with those of the other species, such as with flowering plants and pollinating insects.(no content)Features evolved for one purpose may be co-opted for a different one, as when the insulating feathers of dinosaurs were co-opted for bird flight.

## Human Adaptations

Humans living in Northern Asia and the Arctic have evolved the ability to develop thick layers of fat on their faces to keep warm. Moreover, the Inuit tend to have flat and broad faces, an adaptation that reduces the likelihood of frostbites.

These search results provide a comprehensive overview of how evolution and adaptation work together to shape life on Earth.

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Fitness (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness_in_humans"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Survival of the fittest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survival_of_the_fittest"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Selection coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_coefficient"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Fecundity selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fecundity_selection"}]

I've completed the web search for "Fitness evolution biology." Here are the key findings:

## Main Concept

In evolutionary biology, fitness is a quantitative representation of individual reproductive success and is equal to the average contribution to the gene pool of the next generation. The biological concept of fitness is defined as reproductive success, best understood in Darwinian terms as "survival of the form that in successive generations will leave most copies of itself."

## Historical Development

J.B.S. Haldane was the first to quantify fitness in terms of the modern evolutionary synthesis of Darwinism and Mendelian genetics starting with his 1924 paper. The concept of inclusive fitness was introduced by W.D. Hamilton in 1964 in his paper on The Genetical Evolution of Social Behaviour.

## Key Related Concepts

**Fitness Landscapes**: Fitness landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.

**Evolutionary Tradeoffs**: An evolutionary tradeoff is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part, where a trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

**Selection Coefficient**: The selection coefficient is a measure used in population genetics to quantify the relative fitness of a genotype compared to other genotypes, and selection coefficients are central to the quantitative description of evolution.

I've completed the web search for "Fitness evolution biology." Here are the key findings:

## Main Concept

In evolutionary biology, fitness is a quantitative representation of individual reproductive success and is equal to the average contribution to the gene pool of the next generation. The biological concept of fitness is defined as reproductive success, best understood in Darwinian terms as "survival of the form that in successive generations will leave most copies of itself."

## Historical Development

J.B.S. Haldane was the first to quantify fitness in terms of the modern evolutionary synthesis of Darwinism and Mendelian genetics starting with his 1924 paper. The concept of inclusive fitness was introduced by W.D. Hamilton in 1964 in his paper on The Genetical Evolution of Social Behaviour.

## Key Related Concepts

**Fitness Landscapes**: Fitness landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.

**Evolutionary Tradeoffs**: An evolutionary tradeoff is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part, where a trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

**Selection Coefficient**: The selection coefficient is a measure used in population genetics to quantify the relative fitness of a genotype compared to other genotypes, and selection coefficients are central to the quantitative description of evolution.

Web search results for query: "Mutation evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Mutation (evolutionary algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_(evolutionary_algorithm)"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Adaptive mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_mutation"},{"title":"Mutation accumulation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_accumulation_theory"},{"title":"Genomic evolution of birds - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genomic_evolution_of_birds"},{"title":"Neutral theory of molecular evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_theory_of_molecular_evolution"},{"title":"Mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation"},{"title":"Infinite sites model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_sites_model"},{"title":"Error threshold (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_threshold_(evolution)"},{"title":"Masatoshi Nei - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masatoshi_Nei"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about mutation and evolution:

## Role of Mutation in Evolution

Mutation is the ultimate source of all genetic variation, providing the raw material on which evolutionary forces such as natural selection can act.(no content)Variation comes from mutations in the genome, reshuffling of genes through sexual reproduction and migration between populations (gene flow).

## Key Evolutionary Processes

The processes that change DNA in a population include natural selection, genetic drift, mutation, and gene flow.(no content)DNA sequences can change through mutations, producing new alleles. If a mutation occurs within a gene, the new allele may affect the trait that the gene controls, altering the phenotype of the organism.

## Types of Mutations

A neutral mutation has no harmful or beneficial effect on the organism. Such mutations occur at a steady rate, forming the basis for the molecular clock. In the neutral theory of molecular evolution, neutral mutations provide genetic drift as the basis for most variation at the molecular level. However, large-scale quantitative mutagenesis screens invariably find that a larger fraction of mutations has harmful effects but always returns a number of beneficial mutations as well; in a screen of all gene deletions in E. coli, 80% of mutations were negative, but 20% were positive.

## Chromosomal Changes

Changes in chromosome number may involve even larger mutations, where segments of the DNA within chromosomes break and then rearrange; for example, in the Homininae, two chromosomes fused to produce human chromosome 2.

Web search results for query: "Transposon genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Transposable element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposable_element"},{"title":"DNA transposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_transposon"},{"title":"Transposons as a genetic tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposons_as_a_genetic_tool"},{"title":"Transposon mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_mutagenesis"},{"title":"Transposase - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposase"},{"title":"Conservative transposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_transposition"},{"title":"Transposon sequencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_sequencing"},{"title":"Retrotransposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrotransposon"},{"title":"P element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_element"},{"title":"Transposon tagging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_tagging"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of transposon genetics based on the search results:

## What Are Transposons?

A transposable element (TE), also called a transposon or jumping gene, is a type of mobile genetic element—a nucleic acid sequence in DNA that can change its position within a genome.(no content)The discovery of mobile genetic elements earned Barbara McClintock a Nobel Prize in 1983.

## Major Classes

Class II TEs comprise less than 2% of the human genome, making the other transposons Class I. The key difference is that Class II TEs move through a DNA intermediate, as opposed to Class I TEs, retrotransposons, that move through an RNA intermediate.

Within these classes, autonomous TEs can move by themselves, whereas non-autonomous TEs require the presence of another TE to move.

## How Transposons Move

In many reactions, the transposon is completely excised from the donor site in what is called a "cut and paste" transposition and inserted into the target DNA to form a simple insertion.(no content)The transpositions are catalyzed by several transposase enzymes. The transposase makes a staggered cut at the target site producing sticky ends, cuts out the DNA transposon and ligates it into the target site.

## Genomic Impact

Transposons have a large influence on gene expression and can be used to determine gene function. In fact, when a transposon inserts itself in a gene, the gene's function will be disrupted.(no content)Transposons do not always excise their elements precisely, sometimes removing the adjacent base pairs; this can lead to merged exons in a process called exon shuffling. Shuffling two unrelated exons can create a novel gene product or, more likely, an intron.

## Research Applications

Transposons can be harnessed as a genetic tool for the analysis of gene and protein function.(no content)Transposons have been manipulated for use in insertional mutagenesis.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fitness landscape"

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Talk:Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"File:DE Meta-Fitness Landscape (Sphere and Rosenbrock).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DE_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(Sphere_and_Rosenbrock).JPG"},{"title":"File:PSO Meta-Fitness Landscape (12 benchmark problems).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PSO_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(12_benchmark_problems).JPG"},{"title":"NK model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NK_model"},{"title":"Evolutionary algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutive_algorithm"},{"title":"Error threshold (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigen's_paradox"}]

## Fitness Landscape

Here's an overview of fitness landscapes based on the search results:

### Definition and Core Concepts

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)In all fitness landscapes, height represents and is a visual metaphor for fitness.

### Characteristics

Fitness landscapes are often conceived of as ranges of mountains with local peaks (points from which all paths are downhill) and valleys (regions from which many paths lead uphill).(no content)A fitness landscape with many local peaks surrounded by deep valleys is called rugged. Conversely, if all genotypes have the same replication rate, a fitness landscape is said to be flat.

### Evolution on Fitness Landscapes

An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape by a series of small genetic changes until a local optimum is reached.(no content)If a local optimum can be found in a reasonable amount of time the fitness landscape is called "easy" and if the time required is exponential then the fitness landscape is called "hard".

### Applications Beyond Biology

Apart from the field of evolutionary biology, the concept of a fitness landscape has also gained importance in evolutionary optimization methods such as genetic algorithms or evolution strategies, where one tries to solve real-world problems by imitating the dynamics of biological evolution.

### Dynamic Fitness Landscapes

Fitness seascapes extend the static fitness-landscape model by allowing the adaptive topography to shift through time or across changing environments, describing adaptive surfaces whose peaks and valleys change in time as selection pressures evolve.

Fitness landscapes are often conceived of as ranges of mountains with local peaks (points from which all paths are downhill) and valleys (regions from which many paths lead uphill).(no content)A fitness landscape with many local peaks surrounded by deep valleys is called rugged. Conversely, if all genotypes have the same replication rate, a fitness landscape is said to be flat.

### Evolution on Fitness Landscapes

An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape by a series of small genetic changes until a local optimum is reached.(no content)If a local optimum can be found in a reasonable amount of time the fitness landscape is called "easy" and if the time required is exponential then the fitness landscape is called "hard".

### Applications Beyond Biology

Apart from the field of evolutionary biology, the concept of a fitness landscape has also gained importance in evolutionary optimization methods such as genetic algorithms or evolution strategies, where one tries to solve real-world problems by imitating the dynamics of biological evolution.

### Dynamic Fitness Landscapes

Fitness seascapes extend the static fitness-landscape model by allowing the adaptive topography to shift through time or across changing environments, describing adaptive surfaces whose peaks and valleys change in time as selection pressures evolve.

Web search results for query: "Ecotype biology"

Links: [{"title":"Ecotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecotype"},{"title":"Göte Turesson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6te_Turesson"},{"title":"Ecophenotypic variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecophenotypic_variation"},{"title":"Ecological speciation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_speciation"},{"title":"Niche microdifferentiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_microdifferentiation"},{"title":"Category:Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ecology"},{"title":"Ecotope - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecotope"},{"title":"Orca types and populations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orca_types_and_populations"},{"title":"Asclepias tuberosa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asclepias_lutea"},{"title":"Arabidopsis thaliana - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabidopsis_thaliana"}]

## Ecotype Biology

Ecotypes are organisms which belong to the same species but possess different phenotypical features as a result of environmental factors such as elevation, climate and predation.(no content)In evolutionary ecology, an ecotype, sometimes called ecospecies, describes a genetically distinct geographic variety, population, or race within a species, which is genotypically adapted to specific environmental conditions.

### Key Characteristics

Typically, though ecotypes exhibit phenotypic differences (such as in morphology or physiology) stemming from environmental heterogeneity, they are capable of interbreeding with other geographically adjacent ecotypes without loss of fertility or vigor.(no content)An ecotype is different from a subspecies, which may exist across a number of different habitats.

### Origin of the Term

Göte Wilhelm Turesson was a Swedish evolutionary botanist who made significant contributions to ecological genetics, and coined the terms ecotype and agamospecies.(no content)Through a series of experiments, Turresson studied the effect of the environment on heritable plant variation and came up with the term 'ecotype' to denote differences between groups occupying distinct habitats. This, he argued, was a genotypical response of plants to habitat type and it denotes a first step toward isolating reproductive barriers that facilitate the emergence of 'species' via divergence and, ultimately, genetic isolation.

### Formation Process

Niche microdifferentiation is the process a species undergoes to reach genetic diversity within that species; it is the process by which an ecotype is created. This process is regulated by various environmental influences whether they be morphological, spatial, and/or temporal.

### Relationship to Speciation

Ecotypes can be seen in wide geographical distributions and may eventually lead to speciation.(no content)Ecotypes and morphs can be thought of as precursory steps of potential speciation.

Links: [{"title":"E. coli long-term evolution experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._coli_long-term_evolution_experiment"},{"title":"Long-term experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-term_experiment"},{"title":"Talk:E. coli long-term evolution experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:E._coli_long-term_evolution_experiment"},{"title":"Richard Lenski - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Lenski"},{"title":"Experimental evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_evolution"},{"title":"Voice over LTE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_over_LTE"},{"title":"LTE (telecommunication) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LTE_(telecommunication)"},{"title":"Contingency (evolutionary biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonderful_life_theory"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Why Evolution is True - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Why_Evolution_is_True"}]

## Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE)

The E. coli long-term evolution experiment (LTEE) is an ongoing study in experimental evolution begun by Richard Lenski at the University of California, Irvine, carried on by Lenski and colleagues at Michigan State University, and currently overseen by Jeffrey Barrick at the University of Texas at Austin.

### Overview and Duration

It has been tracking genetic changes in 12 initially identical populations of asexual Escherichia coli bacteria since 24 February 1988.(no content)In August 2024, the LTEE populations passed 80,000 generations in the Barrick lab.(no content)The experiment continues to this day, and is now the longest-running (in terms of generations) controlled evolution experiment ever undertaken.

### Key Findings

The most notable adaptation reported so far is the evolution of aerobic growth on citrate, which is unusual in E. coli, in one population at some point between generations 31,000 and 31,500.(no content)Half of the populations have evolved defects in DNA repair that have caused phenotypes marked by elevated mutation rates.

### Purpose

The long-term evolution experiment was designed as an open-ended means of empirical examination of central features of evolution. The experiment was begun with three principal goals: To examine the dynamics of evolution, including the rate of evolutionary change; ... To better understand the relationship between change on the phenotypic and genotypic levels.

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors and rerunning validation

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (starting with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with complete triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors and rerunning validation

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (starting with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Quantifying the local adaptive landscape of a nascent bacterial community" and extracted all key research entities. The analysis includes:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel methodology and findings)

**10 Key Triples Extracted:**

1. **Fitness (biology)** - Uses | Concept - Core metric for measuring adaptive landscape changes
2. **Mutation** - Uses | Concept - Source of genetic variation analyzed
3. **Fitness landscape** - Uses | Concept - Central theoretical framework for adaptive landscapes
4. **Ecotype** - Uses | Concept - Describes the L and S bacterial strains studied
5. **Escherichia coli** - Uses | Data - Model organism used in experiments
6. **E. coli long-term evolution experiment** - Uses | Artifact - Source of the nascent community
7. **Transposable element** - Proposes | Method - Novel genome-wide barcoded library approach
8. **Gene knockout** - Uses | Method - Technique for measuring fitness effects
9. **Epistasis** - Uses | Concept - Genetic interactions shaping the adaptive landscape
10. **Adaptation** - Uses | Concept - Evolutionary adaptation patterns revealed in the study

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED - All 10 triples are properly formatted with correct Wikipedia URLs and satisfy all validation requirements (at least 1 "uses" triple present, at least 1 "proposes" triple for contribution paper).
